SCORE 49-17
Lindstrand, Delaware; Edmunds, Hopkins, Outstanding Performers
Saturday night the Delaware
University swimming team defeated
the johns Hopkins team in the initial meet for each college by a
score of 47 to 19.
The meet was held in the Delaware pool at Newark, Delaware, at
o'clock. A crowd of 850 persons
crowded the pool room to see the
meet; members of the men's and
women's college as well as townspeople of Newark made up the
crowd.
Delaware Shows Strength

Delaware, from the beginning of
the relay, the first event, showed
that they had the stronger team. In
this event Lindstrand, Brown, Murray and Taylor swam for Delaware
and covered the eight lengths of the
pool in the fast time of 1 minute,
49 3/5 seconds. Doeller, Hahn,
Hanhart and Stewart swam for
Hopkins.
The diving event, divided in
halves by the judges in order to
speed up the meet, was won by Sortman, of Delaware, who amassed a
sum of 68.9 points of a possible
115 points given for perfect dives
in those attempted. Myers, who
tried dives worth a score of 117
points, took second, and Donovan,
Hopkins representative with Myers,
took third. His dives would have
amounted to 116 points if each had
been judged worth the maximum
points by the judges.
Doeller Third in Dash

In the 50-yard dash Delaware
took the first two places when Lindstrand and Murray came in ahead
of Doeller, third man, and Stewart,
who swam as Hopkins second entry.
The time for this event was 27 1/5
seconds.
Gordon, Hopkins, placed third in
the 150-yard back stroke. Howell
and Brown, swimming in their own
pool, placed numbers one and two.
Reeder, Hopkins' other swimmer,
came in a close fourth. Brown
finished the race in 2 minutes and
12 3/5 seconds.

quarter-mile swim, Edmunds, swam

following Taylor, Captain of the

DR. M. JOHNSON TO
ADDRESS SUPPER CLUB
Dr. Mordacai Johnson, President of Howard University,
in Washington, will be the
speaker at the meeting of the
University Supper Club, to
be held tonight at 6 o'clock.
The music for the evening
will be furnished by the Morgan College quartet.
Dr. Johnson will speak on
the subject of "Christianity
and the World Race Problem."
He is one of the outstanding
speakers of the country and
has been in demand at all of
the recent national conventions of both the Y. M. C. A.
and the Y. W. C. A., especially
the volunteer conference at
Detroit and the "Y" conference at Milwaukee.
According to the program
committee of the Supper Club,
no one will want to miss this
chance to hear Dr. Johnson.
